channel.title: Comments on: Stripping rows out of file imports
channel.description: A Technical Community for IT Professionals

item.title: By: genomon
item.dc:creator: genomon
item.content:encoded:
“The next solution that will be much easier to implement, maintain and gain performance will follow in a second part to this post.”

Bring it on!
Anxiously awaiting with bated breath…

item.description: Wow, thanks genomon! Feedback like that is really why we keep going on sharing things like this :-)

item.title: By: genomon
item.dc:creator: genomon
item.description: Thanks onpnt! I forwarded a link to my supervisor, who has been struggling with this very issue. Can't wait for part two!
item.content:encoded: Thanks onpnt! I forwarded a link to my supervisor, who has been struggling with this very issue. Can’t wait for part two!

item.title: By: Ted Krueger (onpnt)
item.dc:creator: Ted Krueger (onpnt)
item.content:encoded:
I agree with you Scott. I asked Jamie T. to take a look. It is very possible I am missing something obvious. It may exist and I missed it.

Thanks for the great feedback!

item.title: By: Scott Stauffer
item.dc:creator: Scott Stauffer
item.description: I like this solution, but I did come up with another that does quite similar without any scripting. I guess that means I have to get off my duff and blog about it and reference your blog. I am glad my question inspired a blog post. I think it would make sense to a have a robust component developed to help process flat file headers. This would seem like a great tool for enterprise ETL. I was hoping that there was already a tool. Your solution is great but to it would be nice to have a configurable solution in a task.
item.content:encoded: I like this solution, but I did come up with another that does quite similar without any scripting. I guess that means I have to get off my duff and blog about it and reference your blog. I am glad my question inspired a blog post. I think it would make sense to a have a robust component developed to help process flat file headers. This would seem like a great tool for enterprise ETL. I was hoping that there was already a tool. Your solution is great but to it would be nice to have a configurable solution in a task.

item.title: By: StefBauer
item.dc:creator: StefBauer
item.description: This is cool! ... I have a slight variation on the same problem, wanted to see if you have any thoughts.... The problem I have is an occasional "extra" cr/lf in the file which causes the line to wrap/split in unexpected places. The problem is that the file-reader is reading a row at a time, and those rows get split... any ideas on removing "extra" cr/lf's (leaving the correct one at the end of the row). (not a fixed width file... a delimited csv).
item.content:encoded: This is cool! … I have a slight variation on the same problem, wanted to see if you have any thoughts…. The problem I have is an occasional “extra” cr/lf in the file which causes the line to wrap/split in unexpected places. The problem is that the file-reader is reading a row at a time, and those rows get split… any ideas on removing “extra” cr/lf’s (leaving the correct one at the end of the row). (not a fixed width file… a delimited csv).
